items.content_html:
Description

Changes name of element to fit RFC; repairs history; fixes examples

Motivation

<u> has never been "the Unarticulated Annotation element."

There is no actual HTML1 standard. When we say HTML1, we refer to Tim Berners-Lee's original proposal, which was actually called "HTML Tags," not "HTML." A quick text search shows that underlining is never mentioned.

The <u> tag is introduced in HTML2 RFC 1866, along with most of the other direct text formatting tags, under section 5.7.2. Unlike bold and italic, which have their own subheadings, underline is discussed directly in the 5.7.2 example, which is clear that it means "underline."

No HTML standard ever published by W3C or WhatWG ever said anything otherwise.

The <u> tag is deprecated in HTML 4, and removed in HTML 4.01.

The <u> tag is re-added in HTML5. HTML5 does not give titles to tags at all. This does not give this documentation license to fabricate a new title in contrast with its historical title.

Additional details

HTML2 RFC 1866 section 5.7.2

Related issues and pull requests

  • #23634 , regarding <b>, and
  • #23639 , regarding <i>
items.title: Repair the underline element

items.content_html:
Description

Changes name of element to fit RFC; repairs history; fixes examples

Motivation

<i> has never been "the Idiomatic Text element."

There is no actual HTML1 standard. When we say HTML1, we refer to Tim Berners-Lee's original proposal, which was actually called "HTML Tags," not "HTML." A quick text search shows that the only mention of italics is in a suggestion to browser implementers about how to display <address>.

The <i> tag is introduced in HTML2 RFC 1866, along with most of the other direct text formatting tags, under section 5.7.2. <i> is specified by 5.7.2.2, which is clear that this means "italics."

No HTML standard ever published by W3C or WhatWG ever said anything otherwise.

The <i> tag is deprecated in HTML 4, and removed in HTML 4.01.

In the meantime, much of the explanatory text is also false.

Italics are not used for readability; they significantly reduce readability.

Whereas rules for when italics are appropriate vary between traditions (eg the lists here for CMoS, SaW, APS, and MLAS are actually quite different,) none of them support almost any of these usage claims. Given that there is not a clear right and wrong, and that this tag is disavowed, it seems inappropriate to give usage contexts at all, but rather that suggestions should be to avoid its use, and to explain its historical use.

The claims about <i> somehow "no longer meaning italic because semantics" have been wholesale removed. <i> has never meant anything other than italic. It went from italic in html2 to removed in html4.01, and there was never anything inbetween. This was just fabricated, and it has propagated to other documentation.

Additional details

HTML2 RFC 1866 section 5.7.2.2

Related issues and pull requests

#23634 , regarding <b>
items.title: Repair italic element by renaming, removing false claims, rewriting core text

items.content_html:
This has never been called the "bring attention to" element in any HTML standard.

This is actually the bold element, and Mozilla documentation should not be getting this wrong.

Description

Corrects the name of the <b> element in documentation.

Replaces the "when to use" section with one that says "do not use this, because it's been deprecated since 1999." The previous "when to use" section gave instructions that have been wrong for 24 years.

Motivation

Someone decided to pretend that this is called the "bring attention to" element. This is not true, and never has been true.
items.title: Repair bold element

items.content_html:
Description

Any tabindex value suffices for an element to be focusable and thus emit keyboard events. The documentation implies that only tabindex value -1 can do that.

Motivation

The phrase to be improved suggests that keyboard events are not emitted when the tabindex attribute of the emitting element has value other than -1. In reality, based on MDN, WHATWG, and SO, any tabindex value makes the element focusable. All focusable elements receive keyboard events, see w3c keyboard event order. To be sure, I tested that this is the case with Firefox 74 and Chrome 108.

However, the tab key and keyboard events are in temporal conflict. The tabindex value 0 and above make the element reachable by pressing the tab key. The special tabindex value -1 means that the element cannot be navigated to by pressing the tab key. The keyboard events are emitted when a key is pressed, including the tab key. Thus pressing a tab key either a) emits a keyboard event without changing focus, b) changes focus without emitting the keyboard event, or c) emits the keyboard event and then changes focus. It is unclear which of these happens. Therefore the tabindex value -1 has a special ability to avoid the conflict by not allowing tabbing to reach the keyboard target element. This conflict might have motivated the original author to limit the value to -1.

W3C keyboard event order docs mention this conflict by stating "The event target might change between different key events. For example, a keydown event for the Tab key will likely have a different event target than the keyup event on the same keystroke." This implies that the W3C recommendation is the c) outcome: emit keyboard event and then switch focus.

All in all, any tabindex value will do for element to emit keydown.

Additional details

MDN tabindex
WHATWG tabindex attribute
W3C keyboard event order
items.title: Relax tabindex value

items.content_html:
I've added an impressive web technology demo to the list. It is a 3D mobile web build of Subway Surfers (2B+ downloads in the app store). It is created with Pixi.js and WebGL and runs well on a wide range of lower tier mobile phones.

Created a new link entry plus description

It is the first top 3D titles I've seen that works really well in the mobile web browser.

No related resources

Description

Images on this page about the element don't work as intended when using dark mode. You cannot see the black edges & borders, which are quite relevant.

I added some white padding around them.

Motivation

Lines & borders of these images where invisible in dark mode.

Additional details

I also made all images of equal size for visual appearance.

items.content_html:
Description

Update the general description for the <b> element.

The last sentence I included is extra information, and could probably be omitted (and may not even be correct if I am misunderstanding the application of the deprecated Boldface element).

Motivation

The existing description is worded somewhat confusingly, and leaves some use cases implied, plus the "instead" clause as written appears to only refer to styling but is meant to refer to styling and importance.

This rewritten description is more clear without being significantly more wordy.
items.title: Update the description for `<b>`
